BILL NUMBER:S1437

TITLE OF BILL:

An act
to amend the tax law, in relation to tax credits provided for solar
energy system equipment

PURPOSE:

This bill will extend the current tax credit provided for the purchase
and installation of solar energy equipment to individuals who install
and the lease solar energy equipment.

SUMMARY OF PROVISIONS:

Section 1. Paragraph 2 of subsection (g-1) of section 606 of the tax
law is amended to add to section: (A) extending the tax credit to(ii)
an individual who leases solar energy equipment owned and installed
by a third party as long as the lease agreement spans at least 10
years, resides within the State of New York, and is the principal
residence of the tax payer. (iii) an individual who purchases the
power under a lease agreement that spans at least 10 years where the
power purchased is generated by solar energy equipment owned and
installed by a third party.

Section (C)-specifies the qualified expenditures covered by the
purchase of solar energy

New section-(D) expands qualified expenditures covered to include the
amount equal to all payments to be made under a lease agreement
including any upfront costs.

JUSTIFICATION:

This bill will increase and encourage the use of alternative and
renewable energy by extending the tax credits received by the owners
of solar energy equipment to individuals who lease such equipment.
Purchasing, installing and maintaining this type of equipment can be
costly and complex therefore deterring some consumers from utilizing
this type of renewable energy.
contracting with companies who provide these services provides an
opportunity for a consumer to reduce their energy costs and continues
to encourage the use of renewable energy.

The impacts of climate change have made abundantly clear the need to
reduce our carbon footprint. However, for a greater impact to occur
it will require that everyone be involved in some way. This bill
provides an opportunity and
incentive for more consumers to take advantage of solar power
generation, reduce C02 emissions and reduce their own energy costs.

LEGISLATIVE. HISTORY:

S.8190; Passed Senate

FISCAL IMPLICATIONS:

To be determined.

EFFECTIVE DATE:

Immediately and shall be deemed to have been in full force and effect
on and after January 1, 2011.
